This is going to be the Largest Space Craft ever made in the history of Mankind , so is the BFG . Super exciting stuff SpaceX has been doing over the Past years . Landing 1 first stage then all 3 , recovering fairings . Bringing back space flight to the united states. Just purely absolutely Amazing stuff , I'm hoping some of this stuff happens in the near future, of going to the moon again or to mars or where ever so my grandmother can see it . She got to see the first moon landing & the several others after it . So I'd be cool if she could get to see it be done again in modern times with modern space craft. As she's worked on aircraft manufacturing like Lockheed martin, Boeing & Edwards air field base & testing facility & with astronauts here in sothern California & has gotten to introduce me to several of them & go into a space shuttle while ISS was being built & into some amazing air craft like the SR71 black bird , the B2 bomber F16 or F18 just a ton of cool stuff to do as a kid . I'm super thankful for being able to meet the people I met & do some of the things I did. As well as getting to see the Modern Space race in AMERICA .

That flame at the top is the vent port for the methane. Its igniting from the engine plume as it aborts. This doesn't happen with RP1 because its a liquid and isn't vented.  This is another problem SpaceX will have to solve... What to do with the venting methane.

A possibility: it seems the top vent of the methane tank is set to, in case of abort and sudden engine shutdown, open up and be a flare. This burns off the pressurized methane to keep it from leaking somewhere else. Because if the tank is at full pressure to feed fuel to the engine, and the engine shuts down, that pressure will want to go somewhere, e.i. leak.

If I've actually come up with the right answer, then: did this feature fail on the last test? Was that small flame at the top supposed to be this large flare? Failed, thus a fuel line breach occurred at the base. And we saw the rest.
